messages.author: cbentzel
messages.text: Should linux be removed from the name?

messages.author: Paweł Hajdan Jr.
messages.text:
On 2011/08/18 21:21:17, cbentzel wrote:
> Should linux be removed from the name? 

This follows the convention used for gnome-keyring. I can update the name if you want.

messages.author: cbentzel
messages.text:
On 2011/08/18 23:30:32, Paweł Hajdan Jr. wrote:
> On 2011/08/18 21:21:17, cbentzel wrote:
> > Should linux be removed from the name? 
> 
> This follows the convention used for gnome-keyring. I can update the name if you
> want.

This is fine for consistency.

messages.author: cbentzel
messages.text:
Not a bad thing - but was this needed? 

The gssapi.h header in net/third_party has it defined as a void*, and casts from void* to other types are allowed.

Also, this may need to be a static_cast rather than a reinterpret_cast

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/310451/should-i-use-static-cast-or-reinterpret-cast-when-casting-a-void-to-whatever

messages.author: Paweł Hajdan Jr.
messages.text:
On 2011/08/18 21:21:17, cbentzel wrote:
> Not a bad thing - but was this needed? 
> 
> The gssapi.h header in net/third_party has it defined as a void*, and casts from
> void* to other types are allowed.
> 
> Also, this may need to be a static_cast rather than a reinterpret_cast
> 
> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/310451/should-i-use-static-cast-or-reinterpret-cast-when-casting-a-void-to-whatever
> 

when using the system header static_cast doesn't work:

net/http/mock_gssapi_library_posix.cc:281: error: invalid static_cast from type ‘net::test::GssNameMockImpl*’ to type ‘gss_name_struct*’

messages.author: cbentzel
messages.text:
On 2011/08/18 23:30:32, Paweł Hajdan Jr. wrote:
> On 2011/08/18 21:21:17, cbentzel wrote:
> > Not a bad thing - but was this needed? 
> > 
> > The gssapi.h header in net/third_party has it defined as a void*, and casts
> from
> > void* to other types are allowed.
> > 
> > Also, this may need to be a static_cast rather than a reinterpret_cast
> > 
> >
> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/310451/should-i-use-static-cast-or-reinterpret-cast-when-casting-a-void-to-whatever
> > 
> 
> when using the system header static_cast doesn't work:
> 
> net/http/mock_gssapi_library_posix.cc:281: error: invalid static_cast from type
> ‘net::test::GssNameMockImpl*’ to type ‘gss_name_struct*’

Ah, so gss_name_t is no longer a void* in the system gssapi.h you are building on.

This is probably OK. I believe reinterpret_cast is still OK here.

messages.author: Evan Martin
messages.text: Maybe add a comment here explaining that this test doesn't make sense with non-dlopen kerberos.

messages.author: wtc
messages.text:
Note that there is only one SONAME for MIT Kerberos in this
table.

This implies that if we standardize on MIT Kerberos, then we
can simply link with -lgssapi_krb5 and the binary will work
on FC, Suse10, Debian.

messages.author: Paweł Hajdan Jr.
messages.text:
On 2011/08/23 00:56:25, wtc wrote:
> Note that there is only one SONAME for MIT Kerberos in this
> table.
> 
> This implies that if we standardize on MIT Kerberos, then we
> can simply link with -lgssapi_krb5 and the binary will work
> on FC, Suse10, Debian.

This also implies that we'd be broken with Heimdal.

messages.author: cbentzel
messages.text: Is the third_party one included in the search path? Or is this using the system one always, and we assume that if you build without USE_KERBEROS that gssapi.h is installed?

messages.author: Paweł Hajdan Jr.
messages.text:
On 2011/08/18 21:21:17, cbentzel wrote:
> Is the third_party one included in the search path? Or is this using the system
> one always, and we assume that if you build without USE_KERBEROS that gssapi.h
> is installed?

This is using the system one. When not using Kerberos we're not using this file.

messages.author: cbentzel
messages.text:
On 2011/08/18 23:30:32, Paweł Hajdan Jr. wrote:
> On 2011/08/18 21:21:17, cbentzel wrote:
> > Is the third_party one included in the search path? Or is this using the
> system
> > one always, and we assume that if you build without USE_KERBEROS that gssapi.h
> > is installed?
> 
> This is using the system one. When not using Kerberos we're not using this file.

What I'm asking is whether all developer machines have a system level gssapi.h installed and on the include path, as well as all build bots. You may need to modify install-build-deps.sh. You should also remove net/third_party/gssapi/gssapi.h in this CL.
